problem:
Question: 
\begin{table}[h]
    \centering
    \begin{tabular}{l r}
        \hline
        \textbf{HEIR JORDAN CORPORATION} & \\
        \textbf{Income Statement} & \\
        \hline
        Sales & \$32,000 \\
        Costs & \$12,900 \\
        \\
        Taxable income & \$19,100 \\
        Taxes (34\%) & \$6,494 \\
        \\
        Net income & \$12,606 \\
        \\
        Dividends & \$4,800 \\
        Addition to retained earnings & \$7,806 \\
        \hline
    \end{tabular}
\end{table}


\begin{table}[h]
    \centering
    \caption{HEIR JORDAN CORPORATION \\ Balance Sheet}
    \begin{tabular}{lcl}
        \textbf{Assets} & \textbf{Percentage} & \\
        $ & \textbf{of Sales} & \\
        \hline
        Current assets & & \\
        Cash & $ 3,650 & \underline{} \\
        Accounts receivable & 7,200 & \underline{} \\
        Inventory & 6,300 & \underline{} \\
        Total & $17,150 & \underline{} \\
        \\
        Fixed assets & & \\
        Net plant and equipment & $31,500 & \underline{} \\
        \\
        Total assets & $48,650 & \underline{} \\
        \hline
        \\
        \textbf{Liabilities and Owners’ Equity} & \textbf{Percentage} & \\
        $ & \textbf{of Sales} & \\
        \hline
        Current liabilities & & \\
        Accounts payable & $ 2,900 & \underline{} \\
        Notes payable & 7,600 & \underline{} \\
        Total & $10,500 & \underline{} \\
        Long-term debt & 21,000 & \\
        \\
        Owners’ equity & & \\
        Common stock and paid-in surplus & $15,000 & \underline{} \\
        Retained earnings & 2,150 & \underline{} \\
        Total & $17,150 & \underline{} \\
        \\
        Total liabilities and owners’ equity & $48,650 & \underline{} \\
    \end{tabular}
\end{table}

The income statement and balance sheet for the Heir Jordan Corporation follows. Assume a 15 percent increase in sales, no new external debt or equity financing, and a constant payout ratio.What is the projected addition to retained earnings? (Unit: dollar)
reasoning: Using the 15% sales increase, projected sales are 36,800 (Steps S4/S4_calc). With all costs assumed variable, projected costs are 14,835 (Steps S5–S6/S6_calc), so projected taxable income is 21,965 (Steps S7/S7_calc). Applying the 34% tax rate yields taxes of 21,965 × 0.34 = 7,468.10 (S8), leaving projected net income of 21,965 − 7,468.10 = 14,496.90 (S9). The original payout ratio is 4,800 ÷ 12,606 ≈ 0.3808769 (Steps S2/S2_calc), so projected dividends are 14,496.90 × 0.3808769 ≈ 5,490.28 (S10). The projected addition to retained earnings is then 14,496.90 − 5,490.28 ≈ 11,006.62 (S11). As a check, dividends plus retained earnings equals projected net income and the payout ratio is preserved (S12).

The income statement and balance sheet for the Heir Jordan Corporation follows. Assume a 15 percent increase in sales, no new external debt or equity financing, and a constant payout ratio.What is the projected addition to retained earnings? (Unit: dollar)
state.goal: Compute the projected addition to retained earnings (a single numeric dollar amount, e.g., 9000 or 9000.00, no currency symbol required unless later specified).
givens: Balance sheet totals: Total assets = $48,650; Total liabilities and owners’ equity = $48,650
Asset breakdown: Cash = $3,650; Accounts receivable = $7,200; Inventory = $6,300; Net plant and equipment = $31,500
Liability and equity breakdown: Accounts payable = $2,900; Notes payable = $7,600; Long-term debt = $21,000; Common stock & paid-in surplus = $15,000; Retained earnings = $2,150
Assumption: No new external debt or equity financing
Assumption: Constant payout ratio (dividends / net income remains the same)
unknowns: Assumed relationship between sales and costs (e.g., are costs proportional to sales or partly fixed?)
Projected costs at the new sales level
Projected taxable income at the new sales level
Projected taxes at the new sales level
Projected net income at the new sales level
Projected dividends at the new net income level (using constant payout ratio)
Projected addition to retained earnings (net income − dividends) at the new sales level
invariants: Use the same tax rate of 34% for projected taxes unless explicitly changed.
Maintain a constant payout ratio: projected dividends / projected net income must equal current dividends / current net income.

No external financing: any growth must be supported by internally generated funds (retained earnings) and spontaneously changing items; however, for this question, only the projected addition to retained earnings is needed.
All money values must be in dollars.
Final answer must be a single numeric value in dollars; do not include intermediate steps in the final output.
All numerical calculations MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed.

plan.title: Extract numerical data and assumptions from the income statement
plan.description: List clearly the current values: sales, costs, taxable income, tax rate, taxes, net income, dividends, and current addition to retained earnings from the income statement. No calculations here; just structured extraction.
plan.expected_output: A structured summary (e.g., dictionary-style list) of current income statement figures and the tax rate.

plan.title: Compute current payout ratio
plan.description: Determine the payout ratio as current dividends divided by current net income using the extracted numbers. MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed.
plan.expected_output: Numeric value for the current payout ratio (a decimal, e.g., 0.38...), showing how much of net income is paid out as dividends.

plan.title: Explicit calculation for Compute current payout ratio
plan.description: CRITICAL: This calculation MUST use Python tool. Break down: Determine the payout ratio as current dividends divided by current net income using the extracted numbers. plan.expected_output: Numeric value for the current payout ratio (a decimal, e.g., 0.38...), showing how much of net income is paid out as dividends.

plan.title: Confirm implied retention ratio
plan.description: Compute the retention ratio as 1 minus the payout ratio, and verify it is consistent with current addition to retained earnings divided by net income. MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed.
plan.expected_output: Numeric value for the retention ratio and a check that it matches (addition to retained earnings / net income) within rounding error.
plan.result: Retention ratio ≈ 0.6191; matches addition_to_retained_earnings / net_income within rounding (both ≈ 0.6191).

plan.result: Assume all operating costs are fully variable and increase in direct proportion to sales; therefore, when sales rise by 15%, total costs also rise by 15%.

plan.title: Compute projected taxable income from projected sales and costs

plan.title: Explicit calculation for Compute projected taxable income from projected sales and costs

plan.title: Compute projected taxes using the tax rate
plan.description: Apply the 34% tax rate to the projected taxable income to determine projected taxes. MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed.

plan.title: Compute projected net income
plan.description: Compute projected net income as projected taxable income minus projected taxes. MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed.

plan.title: Compute projected dividends using constant payout ratio
plan.description: Multiply the projected net income from S9 by the payout ratio from S2 to find projected dividends under the constant payout ratio assumption. MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed.

plan.title: Compute projected addition to retained earnings
plan.description: Calculate projected addition to retained earnings as projected net income (from S9) minus projected dividends (from S10). MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed.
plan.expected_output: Projected addition to retained earnings in dollars (this is the final desired quantity).

plan.title: Sanity-check and consistency verification
plan.description: Verify that: (1) projected net income equals projected dividends plus projected addition to retained earnings; (2) the projected payout ratio (projected dividends / projected net income) matches the original payout ratio within rounding error; and (3) the magnitudes (net income and addition to retained earnings) scale reasonably relative to the 15% increase in sales. MUST use Python tool for any ratio or difference calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed.
plan.expected_output: A brief confirmation that all identities and ratios check out, or a note of any discrepancies that would require revisiting earlier steps.

state.final_reasoning: Using the 15% sales increase, projected sales are 36,800 (Steps S4/S4_calc). With all costs assumed variable, projected costs are 14,835 (Steps S5–S6/S6_calc), so projected taxable income is 21,965 (Steps S7/S7_calc). Applying the 34% tax rate yields taxes of 21,965 × 0.34 = 7,468.10 (S8), leaving projected net income of 21,965 − 7,468.10 = 14,496.90 (S9). The original payout ratio is 4,800 ÷ 12,606 ≈ 0.3808769 (Steps S2/S2_calc), so projected dividends are 14,496.90 × 0.3808769 ≈ 5,490.28 (S10). The projected addition to retained earnings is then 14,496.90 − 5,490.28 ≈ 11,006.62 (S11). As a check, dividends plus retained earnings equals projected net income and the payout ratio is preserved (S12).
